docs.lead_paragraph: John Lackey pitched into the eighth inning, and Torii Hunter hit a three-run homer off the rock pile in center field, leading the Los Angeles Angels to a 5-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox in their playoff opener Thursday night. Hunter's shot broke open a scoreless game in the fifth inning and appeared to topple any mental barriers Los Angeles might have faced against the Red Sox, who had ended three of the Angels' past five seasons in the American League division series, winning 9 of 10 games. Boston did not manage an extra-base hit while getting shut out in the playoffs for the first time since Game 2 of the 1995 A.L. division series against Cleveland.
docs.snippet: John Lackey pitched into the eighth inning, and Torii Hunter hit a three-run homer off the rock pile in center field, leading the Los Angeles Angels to a 5-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox in their playoff opener Thursday night.     Hunter's shot...

headline.main: Angels Leave No Doubt in Opener

docs.lead_paragraph: The old lawn at Fenway Park was covered in shadows at 4:27 p.m. Saturday, and Yankees Manager Joe Torre could have put away his sunglasses. In any other season, he would have. Torre was witnessing the clinching of a division title. For the Yankees, it happens every year, but this time was different. This time, the Yankees had to fight harder than they ever had in a decade under Torre.

multimedia.caption: Another A.L. East Title

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: Yankees starter Randy Johnson, left, lasted into the 7th inning to help secure an 8-4 victory over the Red Sox today and New York's eighth straight division title.

multimedia.credit: Yankees starter Randy Johnson, left, lasted into the 7th inning to help secure an 8-4 victory over the Red Sox today and New York's eighth straight division title.

multimedia.caption: Another A.L. East Title

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The Yankees' 8-4 victory over the Red Sox today, coupled with the Indians' a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/01/sports/baseball/02indians-wire.html" 4-3 loss to the White Sox, secured an eighth straight division championship for New York.

multimedia.credit: The Yankees' 8-4 victory over the Red Sox today, coupled with the Indians' a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/01/sports/baseball/02indians-wire.html" 4-3 loss to the White Sox, secured an eighth straight division championship for New York.

multimedia.caption: Another A.L. East Title

legacy.MultimediaSummary3: Gary Sheffield's two-run homer helped lead the Yankees to an 8-4 victory over the Red Sox today. The victory, coupled with the Indians' a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/01/sports/baseball/02indians-wire.html" 4-3 loss to the White Sox, secured an eighth straight division championship for the Yanks.

multimedia.credit: Gary Sheffield's two-run homer helped lead the Yankees to an 8-4 victory over the Red Sox today. docs.snippet: Three months ago, they were a .500 team. But after getting the final out on Saturday, the Yankees were A.L. East champions for the eighth straight season....
